newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico spot peso closes weaker on long bond.
newsitem.headline: Mexico spot peso closes weaker on long bond.

text.p: The Mexican peso reversed its early gains on the 48-hour contract on Wednesday to close slightly weaker as the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond yield climbed back above 7.10 percent and the stock market flagged, traders said.
"The long bond (yield) revived a little after midday and that made some investors begin to acquire positions in dollars, which squeezed the market a bit," one trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour or spot peso closed 0.25 of a centavo weaker to 7.5750/7.5800, while 24-hour peso closed unchanged at 7.5700/7.5750.
Earlier Wednesday, the same-day peso closed two centavos stronger at 7.5510/7.5540.
U.S. 30-year Treasury bond yields peaked at 7.12 percent, compared to 7.08 percent in early trading.
"Foreign investors usually move ahead of economic data which they feel may be unfavorable, which could be why the long bond yield is increasing," one peso trader said.
U.S. employment figures are due out on Friday, which traders said may lead to upside pressure on long-bond rates.
The Mexican stock market's leading index dipped from an early high of 3,309.96 points to around 3,298.05 as the currency market was closing. But stock prices have since inched higher.
